author: {'steamid': '76561197993400405', 'num_games_owned': 3365, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1703624064}
review:
The classic puzzle game Boulderdash, as a roguelike with some action and sandboxy elements. The mechanics are brutal but quite simple to understand. The soundtrack - a morbid chiptune loop - is an abject banger. The skill ceiling is astronomical. It's an odd fit, but I love this game. 

Quarries of Scred, unassuming and crude as it may appear, is a true work of game design art and deserves more recognition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048878529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 815, 'last_played': 1678653920}
review: This is a very fun game to play for a few minutes at a time. Don't jump out of your chair when you move the wrong way and get crushed by a boulder that you didn't notice!

author: {'steamid': '76561198254298991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1575326388}
review: WOULD BE A GOOD GAME IF IT WORKED ON WINDOWS 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 34, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1711771347}
review:
Quarries of Scred is a retro pixel "mining" game, ripping off the mechanic from the 80's game Boulderdash. 

The game doesn't have a working fullscreen, features ugly retro pixel graphics, yet doesn't exceed the original games it was ripping off.  Which you can play for free in an emulator.   And those have a working full screen mode, where this doesn't.  Why would anyone pay $8.50 for a deficient variation of a game they could play for free?  I don't recommend this at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993685687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 440, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1625656722}

author: {'steamid': '76561198012363945', 'num_games_owned': 2121, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1627063086}
review:
Why do i play this game i ask myself? It sure isn't the graphics here that is the reason. I suppose it's because this game has the 'one more try' and 'greed is good' mechanics built in really well as you try to grab as much goodies as you can from the mines without getting squashed by rocks or killed by bugs.  There is a lot of 'C-C64 Boulderdash' mechanics here and that is good. 

Equipment and randomly generated worlds keep things fresh nicely. Just dont buy this for the achievements unless you like them really hard. 

Quite expensive on normal price but definitely worth discounted as a quick session game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010134705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 226, 'playtime_forever': 1188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1660401283}
review:
Quarries of Scred is (smurf)ing hard.
One life.  No hit points.  Most mistakes are instantly fatal.
This is retro style done right kiddies.  This is the sort of game grandma grew up on.
What you are looking at here is a turn-based Boulder-Dash style procedurally generated puzzle game.
You move one step, the environment takes it's turn.  Gravity, as they say, works.  
So there's no dodging out of the way if you make a mistake.  Like I said.  Most of those are instantly fatal.
If you are looking for flashy animation go play a console game.  
C.o.S. could run on my phone.*  Though the controls would (smurf).
A game like this doesn't need high res HD 4K gobledy gook.  They would be wasted here.
This is a life or death puzzle with no room for error.  Animated Font style was the right choice for Scred.
Selva approves.
To sum up.  Like hard puzzle games?  Like stuff that's rando... pardon, procedurally generated, so you can play effectively forever?  Like a steep challenge that is going to kill you over and over till you get it right?  
Buy Caves of Scred.  'Nuf said.


*My phone.  Not your phone.  I'm not sure Zork would run on MY phone.  If you don't know what Zork is go read a book**.



**Book.  Those rectangular things made of paper with all the words inside.  No batteries or internet connection needed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035355941', 'num_games_owned': 7701, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1520897323}
review:
A long, long, long time ago, on a computer made in a galaxy very far away, someone wrote a little game called Splatch. The code was given out in an Amstrad magazine and you could program the game yourself. Splatch was a balderdash clone. You were a rabbit, you hunted for carrots, you ran away from butterflies and you avoided getting squished. It was written in the mid 1980's and it was by far the finest boulder game ever made. 

Quarries of Scred aims to be a fun boulderdash game. And if I'd never played Splatch, I'd maybe say that it was ok. But I do remember Splatch and Quarries of Scred, while making a valiant attempt, doesn't come anywhere near it.

It's ok, but not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1499974443}
review:
Tags: Casual - Twitch & Arcade
Additional Tags: Delete Local Contents & Remove from Library

TLDR: Mechanically simple game is surprisingly disappointing Xbox360 pad not detected or working at all. Slow drudging grind then Bactracking to surface.

Only option is to widescreen play area which is nowhere near full screen. The sound felt appropriate for the title, and actually so did the art. Audiovisually this could had been alright. The core gameplay however is insanely repetitive. With it boiling down to tile navigation priority based on a half baked 2D gravity system where you have to avoid getting crushed. Game has the good taste of allowing you to navigate multiple panes at once so that if you feel stuck on a pane rather than trying to brute force things you could just pick up a different puzzle elsewhere. Gaining coins and converting them at the surface and buying things felt incredibly clunky, Slow paced and repetitive. Sooner or later I would zone out and just get crushed. It was not motivating to put in the effort, just for a slow coin grind. If this had a correct PC implementation I might had soldiered on to confirm 100% that there is not a good game underneath the surface but given the circumstances I will simply dipose of it based on what I have experienced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023666926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1772, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1493634517}
review: What you see is what you get :) If this is what you are looking for then you found it :D Very old school game, can bring you some nostalgia as well as rage quit because it is brutally hard :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197990926332', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1504689915}
review:
My first experience with QoS was at PAX AUS back in 2014. Setup in an arcade machine, this ZZT looking, Boulderdash inspired game kicked my ass that hard I had to sit down.

After getting over the embarassment, I had another go, and another, and another... Turns out, this is quite the awesome little title and well worth a look if you dig tough, but rewarding games.

(And ignore my played time. have spent far, far more time with this after buying it on itch.io originally!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025135104', 'num_games_owned': 3459, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1466808999}
review:
El juego: maneja a un s√≠mbolo ASCII llamado Bob a recolectar m√°s s√≠mbolos ASCII pero teniendo cuidado de no romper la estructura de s√≠mbolos ASCII. (Bob es el personaje que recoge gemas y piedras preciosas mientras evita que se le caiga la tierra y las piedras encima). Claro, tambi√©n el mismo juego es una reminiscencia de la frustraci√≥n y la ira en contra de los teclados burdos y las pantallas monocrom√°ticas. author: {'steamid': '76561197970244175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1463631930}
review: Cool little game that's great if you're looking for a challenge. Requires patience and planning - every time you get smashed by rocks, it's completely your own fault. And you'll definitely get smashed by rocks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022266051', 'num_games_owned': 3249, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1463625317}
review:
[h1]I loved Balderdash back in the 80's and this resembles that a lot -- GREAT!   But, to me it's just got a number of little issues that added up to a 'not fun' game overall for me...[/h1]

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
+ 80's Balderdash feel
+ Quick 'n simple world, game, controls
+ Multiple dig maps next to each to choose from in one randomly generated game world

[h1]MEH:[/h1]
~ I don't get any desire to really go get the difficult diamonds/treasure just because of how the slightest tap of a key for a split second simply ends your game out right.

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
- [b]Windowed only?[/b]  I get it, it's "retro", but we still can't make it full screen, or at least larger than a tiny window?  [i](If you enlarge the screenshots above on the store page, those seem to be 100% views of the game screen)[/i]

- [b]Seems to be next-to-no animation.[/b]  Rocks fall at almost the speed of light in this game.  It'd be nice to see the avalanche let loose.

- [b]Instant death[/b] / game-over by the slightest wrong tap of a key.  No matter how fast you jump into a spot and jump back -- dead.  If there's something that can fall on you, the game simply goes to the Game Over screen with no animation of your action.

In short, what seems to be my main fun-sapping-problem with the game is the idea of... [h1]"One life.  Zero health.  Make no mistakes."[/h1]And to me, that doesn't make for a fun, casual, arcade game.  But looking at the reviews I'm in the vast minority.  Ahh well.  I love the idea of the game, just not this implementation.  Sorry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122258825', 'num_games_owned': 3711, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 1724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1656, 'last_played': 1501199643}
review:
Action Puzzle..hm.. More appropriately it's a patience-puzzle because if you "action" your way though the boulders you're bound to get merged with them! So this is a Boulderdashy game.. Dig some dirt, find "diamonds" and get the Hades out of the planet in your newly purchased spaceship. 
It is a fun, calm and at the same time rage-inducing game with simple graphics and soothing (well for me..) fitting music to go by. There's no rush to finish quick so you can take your time. A save feature would be nice but it's not there at least not at the time of the review.
It is one of those games that [b]if you lose you have none but yourself to blame[/b]
[b]Final Verdict: Non-roman thumbie: üëç ![/b]

PS. [b]If you played Boulderdash[/b] as  a kid, an infant, a grown up or whenever.. you might find it difficult to adapt as it has [b]almost[/b] the same rules but with a basic difference: you can't stand under a rock.. You were warned!

EDIT: [b]If you're looking for easy achievements, this isn't the game to go for[/b]. They're more of a chore and quite hard (artificially) to get. Some, for example, require you to win quite a few games in a row which is quite hard as even a slight mistake will break your stride and it's all over again..

author: {'steamid': '76561197994646788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1455368617}
review: Quarries is a modern take on games like Boulder Dash. It's more than a repeat of those games with modern graphics. It's a modern design applied to those games. Quarries is to Boulder Dash what Shovel Knight is to Megaman.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994679756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1446786372}
review:
RECOMMENDED

Sure, "Quarries of Scred" looks retro and old-school, but unlike so many pretenders, it IS old-school. 

A puzzle game that's simple in theory but silly mistakes are brutally punished. Get too comfortable and you WILL mess up, followed by sharp shouts of "DOH!" and self-inflicted facepalms. Money is collected by digging dirt, and mining gems and other resources, all while avoiding getting squashed or squashing valuables. I'm oversimplifying but careful planning is rewarded. It's a hard but addictive good time. Great little game. If this had been released in 1986 for IBM clones and the C-64, today it would be fondly remembered as a classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044533980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1550516509}
review: Got this game for under ¬£2 and for that money was well worth getting. Not the best game by a long shot but clever in what it does. The only down side is the lack of instructions (even after readin the online manual) it does not tell you what the different items do that you can purchase, or how to use them. The game is 'like' Boulder Dash but harder. The rocks cause instant death if you push the dirt away from under them. The different Retro Styled looks to the game is what made me buy it, and they work great. Nice game to play for 10 minutes or so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062609598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1558511970}
review: I love and hate this game.  It is really fun and has a great sound track, but it is super punishing. You will die over and over. You may even rage quit. That being said, the gameplay is very simple and addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970936447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1446987553}
review:
Few games retain their playability and even fewer increase their playability the more you delve into them. Quarries of Scred  is one such game. It is still one of my favourite PC games and, like all good games, it is easy to learn but difficult to master.

With loving attention to detail, nail-biting escapes from death and Ranklers there's nothing else you really need to know except that purchasing this game is money well spent.

Save Bob. He could do with your help.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040027761', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1443497236}
review:
Quarries of Scred is pretty fun, albeit frustrating but still fun nevertheless.

It's brutal, it's challenging, and it's also pretty satisfying when you can finish a run after grasping the basics of the mechanics

The game itself self-paced which I too enjoy, at some points I feel like rushing through a level, and other times slowly but surely clear the level.

Not to mention the developer, Kale, is a pretty cool person too <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198010751304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2848, 'last_played': 1612067852}
review: Fantastic game. Great soundtrack and a challenging puzzler. Easy to play but hard to control your greed. Definitely one of the most rewarding games I've played. It's simple, balanced, fun and has a lot of replay value.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970521309', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1444644691}
review: A thoroughly modern game wearing the clothes of bygone classics. A masterpiece of simplicity, and predictability. Every time you succeed or fail, it is solely because of your actions - every action has an entirely foreseeable outcome. It's just a pity I remain terrible at it even though I played a bunch of this game prior to picking it up on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970689517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1443528974}
review:
This is a hard and rewarding game. It's endlessly replayable. It's especially fun to compete against friends in the Daily Quarry, which you're only allowed to attempt once per day. 

Whenever you die, it's 100% your fault. You'll see some gems you want to excavate, formulate a plan on how to reach them, and if you don't mess it up you'll walk away with the treasure. I can't overstate how enjoyable it is to clear a Quarry with as many gems as you risk collecting, and managing to get out of there with a high score and your life intact.

One of my favourite indie games, highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025043297', 'num_games_owned': 3678, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1429853693}

author: {'steamid': '76561197975373553', 'num_games_owned': 1873, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 2048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1447284817}
review:
I think this game is great. It's cruel and difficult but fair since you can (almost) only blame yourself when things go to hell. 

Turn based minesweeper-puzzler with some real-time elements mixed in and your worst enemy is your greed and impatience. You have to manage your pace so you wont miss any easy traps. Great risk vs reward.

It might be too little of a game for some, and the graphics are ugly as sin. But the gameplay is solid.

The achievments may just be too brutal. :(

author: {'steamid': '76561197999613406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1463226873}
review:
Reason to play QoS:
- only needs keyboard, so great for laptops & travel gaming
- brilliant "just one more round" gameplay
- lightweight enough to tinker when brain is tired
- complex enough to stretch every last cognitive capacity when brain is doing well
- simple rules that combine to generate fiendish environmental puzzles that will cause you to curse the day you stepped foot in the mines until finally you solve it and TAKE THAT UNIVERSE I AM AN INVINCIBLE AVATAR OF MINING AND <bumps a rock accidentally> <dies> <weeps softly>
- Crabbens is love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996717230', 'num_games_owned': 3649, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1514402833}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001964986', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1444464811}
review: Really great game that reminds me of many many hours lost in front of Boulderdash and Supaplex. The dev is also a fantastic and lovely guy who has done a lot to support his fellow indie devs, and for that I would give him eternal thumbs up. This is a must buy and the different tilesets are a great feature. Music is great too :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198005312887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1444063402}
review:
This is a really authentic retro game, my first PC was a Commodore 64 and I had many arcade conversions for the system, Quarries of Scred plays just like those old classics. There is a nice variety of tilesets that you can switch to, I've played with the C64 tileset and it definitely gives me nostalgic feelings. Is there anything more than that? I think so, it's a solid puzzle game in the style of old arcade games. It's got a good blend of tension and strategy, and of course those moments where you kick yourself for making the wrong move.
There is a bit of the obscurity that those old games are known for though, for example I had to hop on the forums to find out the keybindings, and the help menu in game is very simplistic. Those are nitpicks though, this is a deceptively simple game that works really well at what it set out to be. I think it's worth a look if you want something quick and engaging to play in your downtime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036613737', 'num_games_owned': 1070, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1431288316}

author: {'steamid': '76561198059561891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1434485637}
review:
Quarries of Scred is an object lesson in greed. The more shiny rocks you collect, the closer you are to certain death. In the game you play a poor, hopeless, soul who has been banished to the quarries to pay for his debt. In the quarries you will find all sorts of randomly generated treasure to collect and spend. There are also many, many dangers, mostly in the form of falling rocks, and some moving enemies. The basic gist of Scred is that it's a puzzle game. A very easy to lose and frustrating puzzle game. As you go about mining and collecting gems and treasure, the quarries will shift depending on your actions. Move the wrong dirt block and suddenly you have a avalanche on your hands. Breach the wrong path and suddenly enemies are swarming all over you. Oh did I mention you die in one hit?

Now I can hear you saying, "Wow, it doesn't look that hard. Just got to pay attention."

You would be correct. However the quarries are sadistic in nature. Rocks block your path and must be navigated or enemies destroyed. Just past that seemingly innocent rock is a mountain of shiny treasure. One that could push your high score or help you win the game. However it hardly is ever innocent. I guess the best thing I could say, is it's easier said then actually done.

Well,  just take a look at one of the quarries. Tell me if that looks easy to navigate.

Yeah, and that is just one quarry. They are randomly generated, multi-layered as well. Sometimes offering even great rewards for going deeper. Now let's pretend after dying 50 times, you get the idea of the game and actually start making a dent into the quarries. (True story on my part.) What does one spend his hard earned cash on? Well the ultimate goal is to leave and win the game. However you can divert some of your cash into buying tech that can give you an advantage. There are lasers, mines, gravity inverters, just to name a few of the items. All of these can be used tactically to turn the tables on quarries.

Suddenly winning the game isn't the main goal anymore. The high-score is your true enemy. Beat the game as fast as possible, with as much loot as possible. This is the staple of the game and what makes it entertaining. You've got to be fast. You've got to be smart. 

From a technical aspect, Quarries of Scred is simply designed but well designed. There are some extra game modes thrown into the mix, ranging from time attack games, to dark mode, where you cannot see anything in the mine and must use flares to light the way. Every day there is a new daily challenge that is shared amongst players to see who can attain the highest score. This must be checked through the website sadly, not through the game. All of these add already to the heap of replay value Scred has. 

The look of Scred is something that may draw you in, if you love retro inspired graphics and minimalistic pixel work. On the other hand, it may turn you off completely from the game. I for one have never been a fan of ASCII artwork, mostly due to personal preference. None of that really matters though because Scred comes with a whole selection of graphical styles and choices. These let you choose what flavor and style you want to play the game in. 

Just as the games visuals are inspired by retro old school games, the music and sound effects are as well. While the music tracks are just fine, there are some sound effects that become grating on the ears as they repeat over and over. Not all the sound effects are bad though. Just expect chiptunes. Any fan of retro games will more then likely be happy with what they hear. If not, blast your own music and mine away.

I haven't met many games that have such a rewarding but harsh nature to them. Scred is incredibly fun and replayable. At the same time though, I raged quit a few times. This was due to my inability and not taking the time to plan out what I was going to do. Completing a quarry or beating the game is a truly satisfying experience. One that is hard to describe after all that frustration. Like I mentioned earlier, the game has oodles of replay value. Albeit it isn't the worlds most groundbreaking, innovating puzzle game, its mechanics work very well. It brings back a retro inspired brutality that games sometimes lack during these times. However the game never cheats you. If you die, it is always your fault. It shows what you did wrong and expects you to do better. Games don't do that these days. Most of the time hand feeding you or giving you a bread crumb trail of what to do next instead.

With a fantastic price, fun gameplay and plenty of mining to be done, bang for your buck is guaranteed with Quarries of Scred. Things like controller support, steam achievements are all cherries on top of this evil sundae.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993930568', 'num_games_owned': 5393, 'num_reviews': 480, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1432251867}
review:
Hey guys,
It's annoying that it doesn't have full screen option, it doesn't tell you what the keys are and you can't change them as far as I know. When you want to input your name you can't just type it, you have to enter it like the high score on an arcade machine and the keys don't even repeat...

author: {'steamid': '76561198126111404', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1430879278}
review:
Played this a bunch when I bought it through another website, so don't mind the low hour count. 

An excellent, if brutally difficult puzzle game. You screw up, you're dead. It is ALWAYS your fault when you die.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066241142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1434194176}
review:
"OH GOD THE RANKLER IS GOING TO GET ME I CRUSHED ITS FRIEND IT'S AFTER ME... oh it's stuck." This was me, screaming, at 2 o'clock on a Tuesday morning, as I ran for my life through Scred, trying to avoid being squashed by the boulders that I artfully pushed aside to get to my goal: gems. Precious, precious gems. I was addicted. Not 30 seconds later, I was eaten by a different, seemingly more menacing Rankler and I was faced with the message: "THE RANKLER CHOMPS YOU." repeated in mocking, green text on my UI.

So I tried again. And again. And again. Finding myself immensely enoying trying to dodge my way around boulders (and failing) and accidentally pressing the wrong key at just the wrong time... but to no avail. I died. Over. And over. And over. And over again.

In my most recent playthrough, the reason I am writing this review, I almost finished an entire room... I had maybe a handful of gems and then POOF, it was all gone in a puff of red pixels as I accidentally set off an avalanche that crushed poor Doctopus alive.

In the end, it wasn't Scred that got me... it was my own greed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970638516', 'num_games_owned': 728, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1437177888}
review: As your body is crushed under a boulder your last thoughts are "well i guess i have time for one more game"

author: {'steamid': '76561198045798832', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1465610517}
review: An addictive and clever retro-styled arcade game that wouldn't be out of place in a room with any other classic coin-op games from the 80's. Get it, play it, cry in frustration, play some more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997662673', 'num_games_owned': 2349, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1431226733}
review: I've had this game for a long time. I'm glad it finally made it to Steam. Simple to learn, but hard to master. Pure fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970585953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1430254124}
review:
i love old school games, games like Dig Dug, Boulder Dash all time game, 
it sure is hard game take me back playing Quarries of scred

Well worth the money,

author: {'steamid': '76561197996651470', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1429889644}
review:
Like unforgiving retro arcade games? Then you will like this. 

Don't like unforgiving retro arcade games? This isn't likely to change your mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970287308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1475176508}
review:
Strangely addictive.
Love the simplicity of making Boulder Dash both harder and less stressful.
It leave me sweating for every single move I'm about to make and to sit beside and someone else play is instant heartattack.

The cool features of refining ores into money is a nice touch but the game is enough just fiddling about for hour after hour just clearing the mines for the sake of clearing.

Some charsets feels abit cheap and I miss a proper CRT simulated display, but otherwise the graphics is perfect in it's simplicity.

Best new game I've seen in a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038310096', 'num_games_owned': 899, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1449686701}
review:
Do you remember "Boulder Dash" from the C64 era? Now image you...

...cant hold a stone on your head

...every thing which falls it does in light speed

...the game is twice as hard as it already is

Welcome to Quarries of Scred.

Some EDITS:

First of all it is pretty much addictive in a good way even if everytime you lose is close to a heart attack (if you have the sounds on)...i love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016986810', 'num_games_owned': 892, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1707798657}
review:
This game                                                            ...                                                   ...                                 rocks.


But seriously

It's a nostalgic little game that you can sit down and play for a few rounds while you're needing to pass the time.  It's challenging without being plain statedly unfair, and it's style is ALMOST painfully accurate to it's retro theme.  If It was a mobile (Vita / 3DS) game i'd give it a solid 9/10 for replayablility and bite-sized randomly generated fun, but when i'm on my computer I always feel like there's a different Roguelike I could be playing, like Cataclysm, DoomRL, or Prospector.

Basically what I'm saying is 8/10, would die of happy if I could play it on my Vita. (Which I know would be asking for much.)

For the price point, the game is worth it either way.  It's frustrating in all the right ways, makes you kick yourself when you do something stupid, and never makes you feel like it's cheated you in any way, while still being pleasantly challenging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021179496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1513813475}
review: Quarries of Scred is a brutal game that will end up consuming your interest far more than you expected. I've owned it on itch io for quite some time now and it's a game that I love to open up and try a round every now and then, especially for the daily challenge. Every single mistake you make is entirely your fault, yet somehow you will keep making them. If you're a masochistic player (which I definitely am) then QoS is definitely for you

author: {'steamid': '76561197987043371', 'num_games_owned': 790, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1430841159}
review:
So I bought this game after having been drawn to it by the retro look (those tilesets are freaking brilliant, particularly the ZZT-esque "Sweeney" one) and the obvious Boulderdash-ish puzzle nature of the game.

I had exactly one issue pop up that was a problem, but the dev very quickly pointed out how to fix it; seems like the helpful sort of developer that actually cares enough to stick around and assist if needed, as opposed to some devs that just drop the game, and vanish into the ether... so that's a plus right there.

But after that, smooth sailing so far, and I was able to get into the meat of the game.

Now the game is labeled as an "arcade" style game in the description, but this definitely is heavily focused on the puzzle aspect.  Figuring out just how to manipulate all of those boulders and such in order to get to where you want to go is a huge part of the game.  Most of the time, you can approach this at your own pace, and stop and think if you need to.  You dont need to rush.  And there are some gizmos you can buy that'll allow you to further manipulate the level in order to dig deeper, as sometimes the rocks will be piled up in such a way that you cant get by them by just pushing them or digging.  Learning to use these is an important part of the game, and it surprised me as to just how much they add to it.  Though I havent tried all of them yet.

There are though also some areas that will contain monsters... as you can probably guess, you dont want to touch these.  In those situations, you might have to be ready to move quickly, so you cant ALWAYS proceed at a slow pace.  You can take these guys out by dropping rocks on them, or use the laser gun, or you can try to block them into secluded areas.   Whatever you do, they are definitely a threat, so you need to be careful around them.

Which brings me to the other bit:  The game is PUNISHING.  This is a permadeath game.  You die, that's it, you lose.... no saving and reloading or any of that nonsense.  There IS a way to buy extra lives (called "drones" in-game), but they're very expensive, and you dont start out with any of them.  Most of the time, you get crushed by a boulder or something like that, and BAM, that's it, you're gone.  One hit KO!    And you will die.... over and over and over.  It's not uncommon to have a run that lasts like, 30 seconds.  Or to have one where you're deep in there, you've been going at it for an hour, going for the big points/money and then.... BAM, made a mistake, and rocks happened, and.... yeah, that's it.  There IS an "easy" mode, which I think does things a bit differently (havent tried it myself) but the game is really designed to be played in the normal way.   It definitely seems targeted towards the sort of player that enjoys things like roguelikes, or games like Spelunky with brutal difficulty, quick deaths, and having to start from the very beginning if you lose.

And what really makes things interesting is that there's a definite "greed" aspect to the game.  This one really seems to be designed to be played for a high score... get as much money as you can before finishing (and of course there's a scoreboard to record your best scores, and there are "daily" runs to do as well).  ALL THE TIME, the game will be taunting you with shiny things that you definitely want, but that are in dangerous places, or areas that are hard to get to, or that appear downright inaccessible.  And so you'll go after these things (possibly with some equipment in hand), and you'll take the risk because you want the shiny things, and.... BAM!  Oops, you're dead.  But it's very satisfying to successfully get tons of things out of a dangerous area, particularly as you go deeper and deeper into the quarries.  

The screenshots in the store show what looks like just a single room/screen/board/whatever, but there's actually alot of them, and you'll have access to a bunch of them right from the start (by running off to the left or right at the top).  And there'll be passages that can then lead downwards into even more areas, provided you find a way to get there while not being dead.  So there's a ton of places to explore, and it's all randomly generated.


All in all, I'm so far very much enjoying this one.  I'm probably going to be playing this one pretty frequently... it's definitely my sort of game.  It wont be for everyone, as the difficulty will definitely turn some people away... but if you like the sorts of games that I do, if you like a challenge, and so on.... then definitely buy this one.  Highly recommended and a very pleasant surprise to suddenly find on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040884867', 'num_games_owned': 2434, 'num_reviews': 901, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1497350370}
review:
Yeah this is my kind of game. Someone said Spelunky for hipsters. Thats close. 

I love the ASCII-like tileset. Game is hella addictive as far as going for mad high scores. Kind of has that high-risk high-reward deal that the old Dope Wars series had.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048881923', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1433800209}
review:
A great tool to help you reflect on yourself and answer the question "Is my greed preventing me from succeeding in life (and Scred)?"

Also fantastic for people who like challenging but addictive and rewarding games! I've played many hours before the Steam release, and I'm sure I'll play many more. The price is an absolute steal for the hours of entertainment and pain you can get out of Quarries of Scred. 100% recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043910636', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1691865387}
review:
Failed the daily Scred within 10 seconds and it was all my own fault. 10/10.

The randomly generated Quarries will keep you coming back for more punishment and the Daily Screds will have you nervously inching deeper in the quest of a higher score.

I highly recommend this game, I've played an absolute tonne of it prior to it's Steam release and I'm looking forward to playing even more now it's released!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972211205', 'num_games_owned': 533, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1430657168}
review:
This game is everything I never knew I wanted since I forgot about playing Boulderdash on my cousin's old Macintosh as a kid. 

Maddening difficulty? Check.
Encouraging greed? Check.
Punishing greed? Also check.
Incredibly rewarding? Oh yes. Check.

The plethora of available art styles mean this is a delight to look at whether you prefer C64-inspired graphics or a more modern tileset, and the soundtrack is superb. Easy to play in a few minutes, hard to put down for a few hours.

10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039404318', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1486428122}
review:
Having played this since its release on Itchio, I can recommend this game to players looking for a challenge, punishing rules, and strict turn-based gameplay.

Playing Quarries of Scred is much like playing Chess against the dark bowels of the Earth, horrific subterranean species and your own greed. Each move will lead to fortune and glory or a quick and messy death.

Dig deep, but beware the Quarries of Scred.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986994883', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1449442093}
review:
Do you like Retro Games? Do you  like Games that make you Frustrated? Do you like Games that make you hit your head on the Desk - - - Hard! Then Play Quarries of Scred - guaranteed to give you hours of frustrating entertainment. When you think you are ready to Kick your Computer, you want to play another game. When you think you are going to throw your Keyboard into the Pond, you say, One More Try!

Do I hate this Game? Yes

Do I like this Game? No

Do I absolutely Love this Game? Yes --- Oh Yes!!!

Don't take my word for it - Play it for yourself! Less than a large Mocha at Starbucks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018269996', 'num_games_owned': 1201, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1429756529}
review: Part try and die - part learn what stupid thing you didn't pay attention to this time that caused a boulder to fall on your head - part incremental increase - part OH M GOD ITS 2 IN THE MORNING.. ONE MORE GAME - part retro delight. Quarries has become into one of my go to "pick up" "put down.. fine one more game" - favorites and I'm glad to see it on Steam! Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965475074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1451537008}
review:
Brutal. Challenging. Cruel.

Many things need to be said for a game which can inspire screams of rage, where mistakes are purely your own, but yet - you'll be drawn right back in next time for another round.

The randomised nature of the levels, the assortment of traps within them‚Ä¶ and the tension of moving tile by tile up to the surface when you've got a massive load of gems so you don't accidentally trigger a rockfall‚Ä¶ or worse, is utterly refreshing in this era.

And the Ranklers. Fear them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110935298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1586832445}
review:
Prior to the game being released on Steam I played 100+ hours of Quarries of Scred.
I cannot begin to tell you how great this game is...It is easily in my top 5 games of all time.

Its a simple game but fun and Its extremely replayable. Runs can last from 5 seconds to 2 hours if you want to get really in depth, but if you have some experience with the game I feel most runs go for around 30 minutes to an hour. The game can be very terrifying, I have even jumped from time to time from a death that seemingly came out of no where. One mistep I can assure you will be your last, but making all the right moves and succeeding is one of the most rewarding feelings Ive ever gotten out of a video game.

In closing I cannot reccommend this game enough. The dev is a great great guy with a heart of gold and his game is a tremendous display of art,community, and love of the gaming world. If you havent bought this game yet I urge you to consider doing so!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972385071', 'num_games_owned': 2710, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1429978422}
review: Like Spelunky, but for hipsters. Procedurally generated levels with ASCII-esq art, self-paced puzzling, surprisingly in-depth interaction of systems, daily challenges, made by one guy, I could go on. Highly recommended, been playing quite a bit and now it's finally come to Steam!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053909712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1429752926}
review: For the price of a Big Mac meal you could instead have hours of gameplay in a good Ol'School game. One of them will elevate your blood pressure and the other is a Big Mac. You know what to do, skip the burger and play a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960426881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1426897113}
review:
A self-paced but brutally difficult sort of puzzle game, Quarries of Scred's primary opponent is your own greed. And the Rankler. Don't forget about him.

This game is practically a puzzle roguelike in that your learning will help your later games, but dying means game over. How much money can you collect?

Update: This says pre-release review but I'm talking about the full version!
